page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 96: Line 96:
On the 6th June, crowds of Egyptians dressed in black held demonstrations to honor [[Khaled Said]], a young man from Alexandria who was beaten to death a year ago in a savage attack which was blamed on police. This attack helped inspire the uprising that brought down Egypt's president.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt remembers man whose death sparked revolution|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2011-06-06/world/29628236_1_large-protest-police-abuse-silent-demonstration|accessdate=1 July 2011|newspaper=SFGate.com|date=June 06, 2011}}</ref><ref name="amnesty1">{{cite web|title=A year since Khaled Saidâs death, Egypt still waits for justice|url=http://livewire.amnesty.org/2011/06/06/a-year-since-khaled-saids-death-egypt-still-waits-for-justice/|publisher=Amnesty International|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Pictures of his body, taken by his family in a morgue, caused public outrage that paved the way for the January 2011 uprising.<ref name="amnesty1"/> Hundreds of protesters stood side by side on Stanley Bridge in Alexandria in a silent protest commemorating the death of Said. The protesters neither held pictures or banners of Said, they only carried the Egyptian flag. They then marched to Saidâs familyâs home in Cleopatra. By the time they arrived there, more joined to reach about 1,500. They set a big monitor on the street screening a documentary on Saeidâs case and its development.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hundreds mark anniversary of Khaled Saeid's death in Alexandria, Cairo|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/egypt/hundreds-mark-anniversary-of-khaled-saeids-death-in-alexandria-cairo.html|publisher=thedailynewsegypt.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
On the 6th June, crowds of Egyptians dressed in black held demonstrations to honor [[Khaled Said]], a young man from Alexandria who was beaten to death a year ago in a savage attack which was blamed on police. This attack helped inspire the uprising that brought down Egypt's president.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt remembers man whose death sparked revolution|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2011-06-06/world/29628236_1_large-protest-police-abuse-silent-demonstration|accessdate=1 July 2011|newspaper=SFGate.com|date=June 06, 2011}}</ref><ref name="amnesty1">{{cite web|title=A year since Khaled Saidâs death, Egypt still waits for justice|url=http://livewire.amnesty.org/2011/06/06/a-year-since-khaled-saids-death-egypt-still-waits-for-justice/|publisher=Amnesty International|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Pictures of his body, taken by his family in a morgue, caused public outrage that paved the way for the January 2011 uprising.<ref name="amnesty1"/> Hundreds of protesters stood side by side on Stanley Bridge in Alexandria in a silent protest commemorating the death of Said. The protesters neither held pictures or banners of Said, they only carried the Egyptian flag. They then marched to Saidâs familyâs home in Cleopatra. By the time they arrived there, more joined to reach about 1,500. They set a big monitor on the street screening a documentary on Saeidâs case and its development.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hundreds mark anniversary of Khaled Saeid's death in Alexandria, Cairo|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/egypt/hundreds-mark-anniversary-of-khaled-saeids-death-in-alexandria-cairo.html|publisher=thedailynewsegypt.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
â
On the 12th June an alleged Israeli spy, Ilan Grapel, was arrested by Egyptian authorities who said that Grapel was sent to Egypt to build a team that was âtrying to gather information and data and to monitor the events of the January 25 revolution.".<ref name="newser1">{{cite web|title=Egypt Accuses American of Spying for Israel|url=http://www.newser.com/story/120869/egypt-accuses-american-of-spying-for-israel.html|publisher=newser.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>The authorities also said that Grapel tried to incite violence amongst Egyptian protestors, hoping to spark a face-off with the military âand spread chaos in the Egyptian public and harm the state's political, economic, and social interests.â<ref name="newser1"/> Grapel appears to be the same man who told Haaretz that he moved to Israel three years before its 2006 war with Lebanon and ended up enlisting in the Israeli Defense Force. Israel, however, denies the reports stating that âThere is no such thing, no Israeli agent has been arrested in Egypt,â. âThese reports are false.â Friends and relatives of Grapel said that he is a law student in Atlanta with an avid interest in the Middle East, and not a Mossad agent out to sabotage Egyptâs revolution, as Egyptian authorities have charged. His mother said he arrived in Cairo in May, countering implications that he was involved in protests as early as February. The arrest of 27-year-old Ilan Grapel has sparked fears in Israel that relations with Egypt will sour now that Hosni Mubarak has been deposed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt spy allegations against Israeli denied by family, classmates|url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-06-14/news/29657736_1_israel-and-egypt-egyptian-revolution-mossad|publisher=boston.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
+
On the 12th June an alleged Israeli spy, Ilan Grapel, was arrested by Egyptian authorities who said that Grapel was sent to Egypt to build a team that was âtrying to gather information and data and to monitor the events of the January 25 revolution.".<ref name="newser1">{{cite web|title=Egypt Accuses American of Spying for Israel|url=http://www.newser.com/story/120869/egypt-accuses-american-of-spying-for-israel.html|publisher=newser.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> The authorities also said that Grapel tried to incite violence amongst Egyptian protestors, hoping to spark a face-off with the military âand spread chaos in the Egyptian public and harm the state's political, economic, and social interests.â<ref name="newser1"/> Grapel appears to be the same man who told Haaretz that he moved to Israel three years before its 2006 war with Lebanon and ended up enlisting in the Israeli Defense Force. Israel, however, denies the reports stating that âThere is no such thing, no Israeli agent has been arrested in Egypt,â. âThese reports are false.â Friends and relatives of Grapel said that he is a law student in Atlanta with an avid interest in the Middle East, and not a Mossad agent out to sabotage Egyptâs revolution, as Egyptian authorities have charged. His mother said he arrived in Cairo in May, countering implications that he was involved in protests as early as February. The arrest of 27-year-old Ilan Grapel has sparked fears in Israel that relations with Egypt will sour now that Hosni Mubarak has been deposed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt spy allegations against Israeli denied by family, classmates|url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-06-14/news/29657736_1_israel-and-egypt-egyptian-revolution-mossad|publisher=boston.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
On the 19th June, The military prosecution released the editor-in-chief of [[Al-Fagr]], Adel Hammouda and journalist Rasha Azab without bail pending further investigation. They were both interrogated on charges of publishing false news that disturbed the peace and negligence in the editorial process. Hammouda was released at around 1 pm, while Azab was released at around 4:30 pm after which she immediately led chants of âdown with military rule.â<ref name="thedailynewsegyptcivil">{{cite web|title=Al-Fagr journalists released pending further investigations|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/al-fagr-journalist-released-pending-further-investigations-dp1.html|publisher=thedailynewsegypt.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Azab had written an article about a meeting between SCAF and prominent members of an advocacy group against military trials for civilians called âNo to Military Trialsâ in which group members provided SCAF with proof and evidence of military violations against civilians. Azab said that Major General Hassan El-Roweiny was astonished when he saw the pictures and testimonies. She added that El-Roweiny apologized to one of the female witnesses for being violated in military prison, adding that individual actions donât represent the morals or principles of the army.<ref name="thedailynewsegyptcivil"/>
On the 19th June, The military prosecution released the editor-in-chief of [[Al-Fagr]], Adel Hammouda and journalist Rasha Azab without bail pending further investigation. They were both interrogated on charges of publishing false news that disturbed the peace and negligence in the editorial process. Hammouda was released at around 1 pm, while Azab was released at around 4:30 pm after which she immediately led chants of âdown with military rule.â<ref name="thedailynewsegyptcivil">{{cite web|title=Al-Fagr journalists released pending further investigations|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/al-fagr-journalist-released-pending-further-investigations-dp1.html|publisher=thedailynewsegypt.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Azab had written an article about a meeting between SCAF and prominent members of an advocacy group against military trials for civilians called âNo to Military Trialsâ in which group members provided SCAF with proof and evidence of military violations against civilians. Azab said that Major General Hassan El-Roweiny was astonished when he saw the pictures and testimonies. She added that El-Roweiny apologized to one of the female witnesses for being violated in military prison, adding that individual actions donât represent the morals or principles of the army.<ref name="thedailynewsegyptcivil"/>
Line 112: Line 112:
==July==
==July==
â
[[File:Tahrir Square on July 08 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx</ref> of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 8 July 2011]]
+
[[File:Tahrir Square on July 08 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands<ref name="Ahram08">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx |title=Hundreds of thousands revitalise Egypt's revolution on Determination Friday - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 8 July 2011]]
â
On the 1st July, tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square in Cairo, to voice frustrations with the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for what they perceived to be the slow pace of change, five months after Mubarak's ousting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://channel6newsonline.com/2011/07/thousands-of-egyptians-protest-against-police-brutality/ |title=Channel 6 News Â» Thousands of Egyptians protest against police brutality |publisher=Channel6newsonline.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref> A Facebook page titled "The Second Egyptian Revolution of Rage" reads: "Seeing that the situation, under the leadership of the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, is only going from bad to worse, and since the council has proven from day one that public pressure is the most effective policy for achieving the demands of the legitimate revolution, we have decided to take to the streets and squares [once again] and demonstrate throughout Egypt until our demands are met..."<ref>{{cite news|title=Disappointed with Revolution's Gains, Egyptians Renew Protests|url=http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/5429.htm|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=http://www.memri.org/|date=3 July 2011}}</ref> The main demand of these groups is to combine efforts toward achieving the goals of the revolution, including: banning the trail of civilians by military courts; raising the minimum wage; bringing Mubarak, his sons, and the senior officials of his regime to justice; banning former National Democratic Party (NDP) members from political activity for five years; releasing all political prisoners; purging the police, the legal system, the media, the universities and the banks of members of the former regime; electing new municipal councils and stopping the exportation of natural gas to Israel.<ref>{{cite news|title=Disappointed with Revolution's Gains, Egyptians Renew Protests|url=http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/5429.htm|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=http://www.memri.org/|date=3 July 2011}}</ref>
+
A Facebook page titled "The Second Egyptian Revolution of Rage" reads: "Seeing that the situation, under the leadership of the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, is only going from bad to worse, and since the council has proven from day one that public pressure is the most effective policy for achieving the demands of the legitimate revolution, we have decided to take to the streets and squares [once again] and demonstrate throughout Egypt until our demands are met..."<ref name="memri1">{{cite news|title=Disappointed with Revolution's Gains, Egyptians Renew Protests|url=http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/5429.htm|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=http://www.memri.org/|date=3 July 2011}}</ref> On the 1st July, tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square in Cairo, to voice frustrations with the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for what they perceived to be the slow pace of change, five months after Mubarak's ousting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://channel6newsonline.com/2011/07/thousands-of-egyptians-protest-against-police-brutality/ |title=Channel 6 News Â» Thousands of Egyptians protest against police brutality |publisher=Channel6newsonline.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref>
  +   +
On 4 July 2011, an explosion at the pipeline near [[Nagah]] in the Sinai Peninsula haltied natural gas supplies to Israel and Jordan<ref name=aljazeera040711/>. An official said that armed men with machine guns forced guards at the station to leave before planting explosive charge there<ref name=aljazeera040711/>. This is the third attack on Egyptian gas pipelines since an uprising overthrew Hosni Mubarak<ref name=aljazeera040711/>. There was also a failed attempt to attack the pipeline in March.<ref name=aljazeera040711>{{cite news | agency = [[Al Jazeera]]| url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011740176861868.html | title = Blast hits Egyptian gas pipeline | date = 2011-07-04 | accessdate=2011-07-04}}</ref>
  +   +
The main demand of these groups is to combine efforts toward achieving the goals of the revolution, including: banning the trail of civilians by military courts; raising the minimum wage; bringing Mubarak, his sons, and the senior officials of his regime to justice; banning former National Democratic Party (NDP) members from political activity for five years; releasing all political prisoners; purging the police, the legal system, the media, the universities and the banks of members of the former regime; electing new municipal councils and stopping the exportation of natural gas to Israel.<ref name="memri1"/>
